citation.article-title: A radiation-resistant rod-shaped bacterium Deinobacter grandis gen. nov., sp. nov., with peptidoglycan containing ornithine.

p.s: Deinobacter (Dei. no. bac'ter. Gr. adj. deinos strange or unusual; M.L. n. bacter masculine equivalent of Gr. neut. n. bacterium a rod; M.L. masc. n. Deinobacter unusual rod).
Cells are rod shaped and gram negative.
Cell division is simple binary fission in one plane.
Red or pink water-insoluble pigment is usually produced.
Most strains are resistant to gamma radiation, and the D10 value of the strains is higher than 0.1 megarad.
Electron micrographs of a thin section indicate the presence of unusual cell wall structure with a lightly stained, looped, membranous layer external to the peptidoglycanlike layer.
Interpeptide bridge of the peptidoglycan contains glycine, and peptide subunit contains alanine, glutamic acid, and ornithine.
DNA base composition (G + C) approximates 69 mol%.
In cellular fatty acids, C15:1 and C16:1 are predominant.
